s.text: The message is that there's no escape from the ignominy, not even through the (often lame) one-liners he employs to win them over.

America is a road movie that suggests the impossibility of travel; perhaps Brooks conceived of The Muse as a movie about the creative spirit that would subversively suggest the impossibility--at least in Hollywood--of creation.

America is a road movie that suggests the impossibility of travel; perhaps Brooks conceived of The Muse as a movie about the creative spirit that would subversively suggest the impossibility--at least in Hollywood--of creation.

As it turns out, the movie isn't about the mystery of creativity but rather the New Age idiocy of people who'd accept the idea of a muse--or, by extension, of gurus or smart drugs or the power of cabala.

One thing that separates intuitive artists from hacks and "players" is their difficulty doing even mediocre work when their cylinders aren't firing.
One thing that separates intuitive artists from hacks and "players" is their difficulty doing even mediocre work when their cylinders aren't firing.

Spielberg," Steven is denied "drive-on" privileges; the camera holds on him as he makes the long, grueling hike through the studio compound, and a passing tour bus driver draws attention to his lowly "walk-on" status.

Spielberg," Steven is denied "drive-on" privileges; the camera holds on him as he makes the long, grueling hike through the studio compound, and a passing tour bus driver draws attention to his lowly "walk-on" status.

The heroes of Real Life (1979), Modern Romance (1981), and Lost in America (1985) have their jerky sides (emotionally squeamish viewers tend to find them repellent), but they also have compensatory gifts--chiefly Brooks' urgent babble, in which pleas are made and then restated and then turned inside out in a way that brilliantly (and hilariously) distills neurotic thought processes.
This is familiar Brooksian territory: impotence prolonged and stylized until it turns into Theater of the Absurd.
This is familiar Brooksian territory: impotence prolonged and stylized until it turns into Theater of the Absurd.

Brooks' best scenes operate on an X-ray level of honesty, so that shortcuts, formulas, easy ways out of dramatic jams--stuff that slicker filmmakers can get by with--seem in his work embarrassingly exposed.

Brooks obviously shares his protagonist's insecurity about his position in the industry (in common with Steven, he never knows if he'll get the money to make another film), but the two have little in common where it really counts--artistically.

Brooks obviously shares his protagonist's insecurity about his position in the industry (in common with Steven, he never knows if he'll get the money to make another film), but the two have little in common where it really counts--artistically.
Although he's incredulous, Steven can't afford to pass up a chance to get his "edge" back, especially with a wife (Andie MacDowell) and kids and a house in Pacific Palisades to maintain.
Although he's incredulous, Steven can't afford to pass up a chance to get his "edge" back, especially with a wife (Andie MacDowell) and kids and a house in Pacific Palisades to maintain.
In the absence of true inspiration, they can't fall back on a crafty understanding of what the audience wants because they don't really know what the audience wants.
